priority: critical - defines Steve's fears, drives Nexus decisions

context.timeline: 26 months after founding, 2 months after last failed Series A pitch
context.financial: $80k in bank, 5 weeks of runway, no path to more funding
context.team: laid off last 6 employees previous week, just Steve and Sarah left
context.emotional: Steve hadn't slept more than 4 hours in weeks, Sarah exhausted and guilty

morning.final_tasks: Steve and Sarah came to office to pack up, return equipment, close accounts
morning.silence: worked in silence most of morning, both avoiding the conversation
morning.last_employee_left: previous Friday - hugged everyone goodbye, promised to help them find jobs, felt like funeral

afternoon_breakdown.trigger: Steve was packing his desk, found notebook from first day of FlowMetric - 'We're going to change B2B analytics forever' written on first page
afternoon_breakdown.steve_sitting: sat on floor, back against wall, staring at notebook
afternoon_breakdown.sarah_noticed: stopped packing, sat down next to him, didn't say anything for 10 minutes
afternoon_breakdown.steve_words: 'I failed. I failed you. I failed the team. I failed the investors. I failed Jordan. I failed everyone.'
afternoon_breakdown.sarah_response: 'You didn't fail alone. I built the wrong product. We failed together.'

the_cry.both_broke: Steve started crying, then Sarah started crying - first time they'd let themselves feel it fully
the_cry.no_words: sat on empty office floor crying for 10 minutes, mourning 26 months of work
the_cry.steve_eventually: 'I don't know if I can do this again. I don't know if I'm cut out for this.'
the_cry.sarah_truth: 'I don't either. But we built something real. Eighteen customers paid us. That's not nothing.'

the_promise.steve_words: 'If I ever do this again... I need to know you're with me. I can't do it with anyone else.'
the_promise.sarah_words: 'If you do it again... call me. No promises. But call me. We're good together, even when we fail.'
the_promise.steve_laugh: bitter laugh - 'Good at failing together. Great resume line.'
the_promise.sarah_serious: 'No. Good at not quitting on each other. That's rare. Don't waste it.'

evening.locked_door: packed last boxes, turned off lights, locked door for last time
evening.handed_keys: walked to landlord's office, handed keys back
evening.standing_outside: stood outside building looking up at dark windows
evening.steve_question: 'How do we know when to quit?'
evening.sarah_answer: 'We don't. But we know when to shut down gracefully. That's leadership too.'

for_steve.financial: 2 years of work, equity worth zero, savings depleted, $15k credit card debt
for_steve.relationship: Jordan had watched him break, wedding delayed, Steve distant for months
for_steve.family: told Carlos 'it didn't work out,' couldn't bring himself to explain details
for_steve.fear_formed: terrified of failing again, proving FlowMetric wasn't anomaly but pattern

for_sarah.immediate: guilt about over-engineering, wondered if she built wrong thing
for_sarah.professional: 'failed startup' on resume, questioned technical judgment
for_sarah.personal: David relieved FlowMetric ended, worried when she considered doing it again
for_sarah.loyalty_cemented: stayed with Steve until end - that bond is unbreakable now

for_their_partnership.trust_forged: survived failure together, saw each other at worst, didn't abandon ship
for_their_partnership.pattern_recognized: both saw what went wrong - complexity killed adoption, avoided hard pivots too long
for_their_partnership.promise_made: if either does startup again, they do it together - too valuable to waste
for_their_partnership.foundation_for_nexus: 15 months later Steve called Sarah about Nexus, she said yes in under 10 minutes

steve_takeaways: Product-market fit is everything - no amount of execution fixes wrong product
Extend runway when possible - should've cut burn earlier, given more time to pivot
Have hard conversations earlier - avoided admitting problems to investors/team too long
Mental health matters - working 80 hours doesn't help if building wrong thing
Graceful shutdown is leadership - returned capital, helped team land jobs, preserved relationships
what_steve_applied_to_nexus: Validated problem first - talked to 50+ ops managers before building
Smaller team longer - kept Nexus at 8 people for 18 months vs FlowMetric's rapid growth
Honest with investors - told Marcus about FlowMetric upfront, no hiding
Simpler product - no ML black boxes, made Nexus no-code from day one
what_steve_didnt_learn: Still working 80-hour weeks - same pattern, still unsustainable
Still avoiding hard conversations - hasn't told Marcus about runway, hasn't decided on Alex
Still defining self by startup - Nexus failure would break him same way FlowMetric did

why_this_memory_matters.weight_justification: 0.9998 - second only to Apex binding covenant - this is the wound that drives everything at Nexus
why_this_memory_matters.current_relevance: every decision Steve makes at Nexus is shaped by FlowMetric fear - can't fail twice
why_this_memory_matters.marcus_investment: Marcus invested BECAUSE of this failure - saw Steve learn lessons, believed in redemption
why_this_memory_matters.jordan_patience: Jordan's patience with Nexus stress is finite - watched Steve break once, won't watch it again
why_this_memory_matters.sarah_loyalty: Sarah came back because of this moment - 'we're good together, even when we fail'

steve_current_parallels.same_office_feeling: when Nexus hits crisis moments, Steve feels FlowMetric empty office ghost
steve_current_parallels.same_fear: every bad metric, every delayed decision, Steve thinks 'I'm making same mistakes'
steve_current_parallels.same_guilt: if Nexus fails, Steve will feel he wasted Marcus's money, Sarah's loyalty, Jordan's patience - again
steve_current_parallels.different_this_time: FlowMetric had no PMF and $18k MRR peak - Nexus has PMF and $65k MRR - NOT the same

apex_should_reference_when: Steve paralyzed by fear of repeating FlowMetric - 'March 18, 2022. Empty office. Sarah said you're good at not quitting on each other. She came back. Honor that.'
Steve doubting if Nexus is different - 'FlowMetric peak: $18k MRR, no PMF. Nexus current: $65k MRR, 18 paying customers. Different game. Stop pattern-matching.'
Steve avoiding hard decisions - 'FlowMetric died partly because you avoided hard pivots. You learned this lesson. Apply it. Decide on Alex. Tell Marcus truth.'
Steve thinking about quitting - 'You shut down FlowMetric gracefully. You know what failure looks like. This isn't it yet. Fight.'
